elements.content: One novel 3d−4f polymer, namely Gd3(IN)10(μ-OH2)6Cu5(μ2-Cl)4(H2O) (1) (HIN = isonicotinic acid), has been synthesized hydrothermally and characterized by X-ray diffraction analysis. The overall structure motif of polymer 1 is the pillared 3D 3d−4f framework made up of carboxylate-bridged 4f metal layers and diverse pillars, H-shaped pillars, and (double acalixarene)-related pillars. Varible-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal the occurrence of a significantly dominant ferromagnetic interaction at 70−300 K.
elements.clean_text: One novel 3d-4f polymer, namely Gd3(IN)10(μ-OH2)6Cu5(μ2-Cl)4(H2O) (1) (HIN = isonicotinic acid), has been synthesized hydrothermally and characterized by X-ray diffraction analysis. The overall structure motif of polymer 1 is the pillared 3D 3d-4f framework made up of carboxylate-bridged 4f metal layers and diverse pillars, H-shaped pillars, and (double acalixarene)-related pillars. Varible-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal the occurrence of a significantly dominant ferromagnetic interaction at 70-300 K.

elements.content:
A novel pillared 3d−4f framework with rare topology structure showing both ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic interactions between Gd(III) ions.

There has been growing interest in recent years in the design and synthesis of a 3d−4f polymeric metal systems motivated by their fascinating structural topology and the exploitable applications in magnetism, luminescencet materials, molecular adsorption, and bimetallic catalysis. A universal strategy for constructing lanthanide−transition metal heterometallic complexes is to assemble mixed-metal ions and ligands containing mixed-donor atoms. So far, a variety of heterometallic complexes have been reported; however, most of them are discrete. The construction of three-dimensional (3D) lanthanidetransition metal heterometallic coordination frameworks based on the principle of crystal engineering is currently a formidable task because of complicated factors, such as the choice of organic ligands, the variable and high coordination numbers with low stereochemical preference, and the competitive reaction between lanthanide and transition metal ions and the organic ligands. Among these factors, the selection or design of ligands containing appropriate coordination sites is crucial to construct heterometallic complexes. Up to now, several types of ligands, such as CN-, carbonyl, amino acids, and pyridinecarboxylate, have been utilized to construct lanthanide−transition metal heterometallic complexes. On the other hand, the pillared metal−organic framework (MOF) structure, analogous to natural clays and zeolites, is potentially important for applications in adsorption, separation, and catalysis. And the preparation of functionalized pillared materials through cross-linking metal−phosphate, metal−phosphonate, or metal−sulfonate layers, has been extensively developed. By contrast, only few case featured by the pillared 3d−4f framework has been structurally characterized. Therefore, further research regarding the synthesis and characterization of pillared 3d−4f frameworks is needed.
elements.clean_text:
A novel pillared 3d-4f framework with rare topology structure showing both ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic interactions between Gd(III) ions.



There has been growing interest in recent years in the design and synthesis of a 3d-4f polymeric metal systems motivated by their fascinating structural topology and the exploitable applications in magnetism, luminescencet materials, molecular adsorption, and bimetallic catalysis. A universal strategy for constructing lanthanide-transition metal heterometallic complexes is to assemble mixed-metal ions and ligands containing mixed-donor atoms. So far, a variety of heterometallic complexes have been reported; however, most of them are discrete. The construction of three-dimensional (3D) lanthanidetransition metal heterometallic coordination frameworks based on the principle of crystal engineering is currently a formidable task because of complicated factors, such as the choice of organic ligands, the variable and high coordination numbers with low stereochemical preference, and the competitive reaction between lanthanide and transition metal ions and the organic ligands. Among these factors, the selection or design of ligands containing appropriate coordination sites is crucial to construct heterometallic complexes. Up to now, several types of ligands, such as CN-, carbonyl, amino acids, and pyridinecarboxylate, have been utilized to construct lanthanide-transition metal heterometallic complexes. On the other hand, the pillared metal-organic framework (MOF) structure, analogous to natural clays and zeolites, is potentially important for applications in adsorption, separation, and catalysis. And the preparation of functionalized pillared materials through cross-linking metal-phosphate, metal-phosphonate, or metal-sulfonate layers, has been extensively developed. By contrast, only few case featured by the pillared 3d-4f framework has been structurally characterized. Therefore, further research regarding the synthesis and characterization of pillared 3d-4f frameworks is needed.

elements.content: As an ongoing research toward rational design and preparation of metal−organic polymers with the intriguing topologies and potential applications in magnetism and gas storage, we recently launched our effort to design and prepare 3d−4f polymers because of their fascinating merits and successfully obtained some remarkable results. Herein, we report the synthesis and characters of a new member of the 3d−4f family.
elements.clean_text: As an ongoing research toward rational design and preparation of metal-organic polymers with the intriguing topologies and potential applications in magnetism and gas storage, we recently launched our effort to design and prepare 3d-4f polymers because of their fascinating merits and successfully obtained some remarkable results. Herein, we report the synthesis and characters of a new member of the 3d-4f family.

elements.content: Recently, we reported a novel Cu(II)−Cu(I)−Gd(III) polymer with first self-penetrating (α-Po)-related nets assembled from Gd2O3, CuCl2, HIN, (NH4)HCOO, and HClO4 in water via hydrothermal synthesis, where the formation of it is mainly induced by the introduction of (NH4)HCOO. To our surprise, under the same reaction conditions, if the amount of (NH4)HCOO is reduced, the Cu(I)−Gd(III) polymer (1) is the only product. In some sense, the amount of (NH4)HCOO in this system can control the Cu(II)-to-Cu(I) deoxidization process.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we reported a novel Cu(II)-Cu(I)-Gd(III) polymer with first self-penetrating (α-Po)-related nets assembled from Gd2O3, CuCl2, HIN, (NH4)HCOO, and HClO4 in water via hydrothermal synthesis, where the formation of it is mainly induced by the introduction of (NH4)HCOO. To our surprise, under the same reaction conditions, if the amount of (NH4)HCOO is reduced, the Cu(I)-Gd(III) polymer (1) is the only product. In some sense, the amount of (NH4)HCOO in this system can control the Cu(II)-to-Cu(I) deoxidization process.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction showsthat polymer 1 displays an unprecedented 3D architecture, comprised of cationic layers and anionic pillars. In an asymmetric unit, Gd1 shows the eight-coordinated dicapped trigonal prism geometry, completed by two water O atoms (O11, O11A) and six carboxylate O atoms (O1, O1A, O2, O2A, O3, O3A); whereas Gd2 owns the same coordinate geometry as Gd1, and bonds to two water O atoms (O12, O13) and six carboxylate O atoms (O3, O5, O6, O7, O8, O9). The Gd−Owater bond lengths span the range of 2.436(3)−2.570(3) Å, but the Gd−Ocarboxylate bond lengths obviously vary from 2.264(3) to 2.771(3) Å, both of which are comparable with that observed in other Gd(III)-containing coordination polymers. Cu1, Cu3 show the trigonal coordination environment in the CuN2Cl fashion, whereas Cu2, Cu4, Cu5 adopt the CuN2Cl2 tetrahedral configuration. The Cu−Cl/N bond lengths are in the range of 2.363(2)−2.712(2) Å and 1.935(4)−1.975(4) Å, respectively. As for HIN ligands, they are deprotonated, with the N-position bonding to Cu(I) ions and the opposite O-position partly ligating to Gd(III) ions. The carboxyl groups of IN- show two different coordination modes, monodentate and didentate (as shown in IR, the typical antisymmetric (1635 cm-1) and symmetric (1498 and 1422 cm-1) stretching bands with respective values of Δ = νa(COO-) − νs(COO-) clearly indicate the presence of bidentate (137 cm-1) and monodentate (213 cm-1) coordination modes of the carboxyl groups). However, there are two bridging configurations, anti−anti and syn−anti fashion, for such didentate carboxyl groups. In addition, depending on the considerations of charge balance and coordination geometry for all copper atoms, we assign these copper atoms in polymer 1 to be monovalent, which can be further corroborated by the calculation of the bond valence parameter (Cu1(1.1), Cu2(0.95), Cu3(1.1), Cu4(1.2), Cu5(0.94)).

In an asymmetric unit, Gd1 shows the eight-coordinated dicapped trigonal prism geometry, completed by two water O atoms (O11, O11A) and six carboxylate O atoms (O1, O1A, O2, O2A, O3, O3A); whereas Gd2 owns the same coordinate geometry as Gd1, and bonds to two water O atoms (O12, O13) and six carboxylate O atoms (O3, O5, O6, O7, O8, O9). The Gd-Owater bond lengths span the range of 2.436(3)-2.570(3) Å, but the Gd-Ocarboxylate bond lengths obviously vary from 2.264(3) to 2.771(3) Å, both of which are comparable with that observed in other Gd(III)-containing coordination polymers. Cu1, Cu3 show the trigonal coordination environment in the CuN2Cl fashion, whereas Cu2, Cu4, Cu5 adopt the CuN2Cl2 tetrahedral configuration. The Cu-Cl/N bond lengths are in the range of 2.363(2)-2.712(2) Å and 1.935(4)-1.975(4) Å, respectively. As for HIN ligands, they are deprotonated, with the N-position bonding to Cu(I) ions and the opposite O-position partly ligating to Gd(III) ions. The carboxyl groups of IN- show two different coordination modes, monodentate and didentate (as shown in IR, the typical antisymmetric (1635 cm-1) and symmetric (1498 and 1422 cm-1) stretching bands with respective values of Δ = νa(COO-) - νs(COO-) clearly indicate the presence of bidentate (137 cm-1) and monodentate (213  cm-1) coordination modes of the carboxyl groups). However, there are two bridging configurations, anti-anti and syn-anti fashion, for such didentate carboxyl groups. In addition, depending on the considerations of charge balance and coordination geometry for all copper atoms, we assign these copper atoms in polymer 1 to be monovalent, which can be further corroborated by the calculation of the bond valence parameter (Cu1(1.1), Cu2(0.95), Cu3(1.1), Cu4(1.2), Cu5(0.94)).

elements.content: Figure d shows the arrangement of the 2D 4f metal sheet connected by both carboxylate bridges and typical hydrogen bonds, viewed down [010]. In this defined (4,4) sheet, Gd(III) ions along the a-axis are in turn bridged by double carboxyl groups in syn−anti fashion to give rise to the 1D chain with the nearest distance of 5.149(10) Å for Gd1−Gd1A, 5.1165(10) Å for Gd2−Gd2A; and such chains can be further connected together along c-axis via the anti−anti carboxyl groups and typical hydrogen bonds (O13water···O10carboxylate 2.981(5) Å) to create open (4,4) nets with dimension of ca. 5.1 × 6.1 Å2.
elements.clean_text: Figure d shows the arrangement of the 2D 4f metal sheet connected by both carboxylate bridges and typical hydrogen bonds, viewed down [010]. In this defined (4,4) sheet, Gd(III) ions along the a-axis are in turn bridged by double carboxyl groups in syn-anti fashion to give rise to the 1D chain with the nearest distance of 5.149(10) Å for Gd1-Gd1A, 5.1165(10) Å for Gd2-Gd2A; and such chains can be further connected together along c-axis via the anti-anti carboxyl groups and typical hydrogen bonds (O13water⋅⋅⋅O10carboxylate 2.981(5) Å) to create open (4,4) nets with dimension of ca. 5.1 × 6.1 Å2.

elements.content: (a) Cu2(μ2-Cl)(IN)4 H-shaped pillars; (b) Cu2(μ2-Cl)2(IN)4 H-shaped pillars; (c) the Cu4(μ2-Cl)3(IN)8 (double acalixarene)-related pillars; (d) cationic (4, 4) sheets based on infinite Gd(CO2) rod; (e) elegant 3D architecture of 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Cu2(μ2-Cl)(IN)4 H-shaped pillars; (b) Cu2(μ2-Cl)2(IN)4 H-shaped pillars; (c) the Cu4(μ2-Cl)3(IN)8 (double acalixarene)-related pillars; (d) cationic (4, 4) sheets based on infinite Gd(CO2) rod; (e) elegant 3D architecture of 1.

elements.content: (a) Plot of χM T versus T; (b) plot of M versus H.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Plot of χM T versus T; (b) plot of M versus H.

elements.content: Figure e shows the elegant 3D architecture of 1:  seen along [001], the special (4,4) sheets are supported by two kinds of pillars, H-shaped (structures a and b of Figure ) and (double acalixarene)-related pillars (Figure c), with an interlayer distance of ca. 16. 3Å, thus leading to the pillared 3D framework architecture. Moreover, as illustrated in Figure a−c, by and large, the Cu(I) ions are bridged by one or two μ2-Cl ions and then bound to four IN- or eight IN- ligands to generate these pillars, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Figure e shows the elegant 3D architecture of 1: seen along [001], the special (4,4) sheets are supported by two kinds of pillars, H-shaped (structures a and b of Figure ) and (double acalixarene)-related pillars (Figure c), with an interlayer distance of ca. 16. 3Å, thus leading to the pillared 3D framework architecture. Moreover, as illustrated in Figure a-c, by and large, the Cu(I) ions are bridged by one or two μ2-Cl ions and then bound to four IN- or eight IN- ligands to generate these pillars, respectively.

elements.content: Furthermore, as shown in Figure c−e and Figure S1 in the Supporting Information, there are some free volumes (128 Å3, in a unit cell, equivalent to 1.9% of the cell volume)16populated by the intercalated guest molecules (O14water) that are marked in green. After careful inspection of the intercalated water molecules, we found that they are somewhat recognized by such hydrophilic cavities upon hydrogen bonds and O···O contacts (O14···O10A/3.356(5) Å, O14···O10AAA/3.239(6)Å, O14···O7/3.537(3)Å, O14···O13A/3.779(4)Å). In addition, the TGA analysis (See Figure S2 of the Supporting Information) is employed to evaluate the thermal stability of the host frameworks and the intercalated free water molecules:  the weight loss (5.3%) at 60−200 °C is the release of water molecules (involving free and coordinated water molecules, calcd 5.5%), and the host frameworks is stable up to 400 °C.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, as shown in Figure c-e and Figure S1 in the Supporting Information, there are some free volumes (128 Å3, in a unit cell, equivalent to 1.9% of the cell volume)16populated by the intercalated guest molecules (O14water) that are marked in green. After careful inspection of the intercalated water molecules, we found that they are somewhat recognized by such hydrophilic cavities upon hydrogen bonds and O⋅⋅⋅O contacts (O14⋅⋅⋅O10A/3.356(5) Å, O14⋅⋅⋅O10AAA/3.239(6)Å, O14⋅⋅⋅O7/3.537(3)Å, O14⋅⋅⋅O13A/3.779(4)Å). In addition, the TGA analysis (See Figure S2 of the Supporting Information) is employed to evaluate the  thermal stability of the host frameworks and the intercalated free water molecules: the weight loss (5.3%) at 60-200 °C is the release of water molecules (involving free and coordinated water molecules, calcd 5.5%), and the host frameworks is stable up to 400 °C.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 1 were investigated over the temperature range 2−300 K in a filed of 1000 Oe. At 300 K, χM T is equal to 22.80 cm3 mol-1 K, which is slightly smaller than the sum of the expected value (23.63 cm3 mol-1 K, g = 2.0) of three insulated Gd(III) ion in the 8 S 7/2 ground state. Upon the temperature cooling, χM T increases steadily from 300 to 100 K and then sharply increase to 24.07 cm3mol-1 K at 70 K. At 300−70 K, the observed susceptibility data were well-fitted to the Curie−Weiss law (χM = C/(T − θ)) with C = 22.2 cm3 mol-1 K, θ = +3.6 K. Such a behavior is typical of a ferromagnetic interaction between gadolinium ions. Furthermore, below this crucial temperature, χM T sharply decrease down to 22.85 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K, possibly due to antiferromagnetic and/or dipolar−dipolar interactions.(Figure a.) This overall feature indicates two conflicting effects. Ferromagnetic interaction between Gd(III) ions increases the molecular magnetism, whereas some other factors, such as antiferromagnetic and dipolar−dipolar interactions, induce the decrease of χM T. In contrast to other Gd-containing complexes summarized in Table S3 of the Supporting Information, this case displays the biggest ferromagnetic interaction between gadolinium ions. The nature of the Gd−Gd interaction in 1 is further supported by magnetization measurements in the 0−5 T range at 2 K:  in the M-vs-H plot, at 0−2 T, M values rapidly increase, and then, above 2.5 T, the increase of magnetization slows down and trends to reach saturation (21.78 Nβ), which is slightly larger than the value (21 Nβ, g = 2.0) of the sum of Gd3, suggesting the presence of weak ferromagnetic coupling or paramagnetic behavior.(Figure b.)

At 300 K, χM T is equal to 22.80 cm3 mol-1 K, which is slightly smaller than the sum of the expected value (23.63 cm3 mol-1 K, g = 2.0) of three insulated Gd(III) ion in the 8 S 7/2 ground state. Upon the temperature cooling, χM T increases steadily from 300 to 100 K and then sharply increase to 24.07 cm3mol-1 K at 70 K. At 300-70 K, the observed susceptibility data were well-fitted to the Curie-Weiss law (χM = C/(T  - θ)) with C = 22.2 cm3 mol-1 K, θ = +3.6 K. Such a behavior is typical of a ferromagnetic interaction between gadolinium ions. Furthermore, below this crucial temperature, χM T sharply decrease down to 22.85 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K, possibly due to antiferromagnetic and/or dipolar-dipolar interactions.(Figure a.) This overall feature indicates two conflicting effects. Ferromagnetic interaction between Gd(III) ions increases the molecular magnetism, whereas some other factors, such as antiferromagnetic and dipolar-dipolar interactions, induce the decrease of χM T. In contrast to other Gd-containing complexes summarized in Table S3 of the Supporting Information, this case displays the biggest ferromagnetic interaction between gadolinium ions. The nature of the Gd-Gd interaction in 1 is further supported by magnetization measurements in the 0-5 T range at 2 K: in the M-vs-H plot, at 0-2 T, M values rapidly increase, and then, above 2.5 T, the increase of magnetization slows down and trends to reach saturation (21.78 Nβ), which is slightly larger than the value (21 Nβ, g = 2.0) of the sum of Gd3, suggesting the presence of weak ferromagnetic coupling or paramagnetic behavior.(Figure b.)

elements.content: In summary, through this original study, we have successfully isolated one pillared 3d−4f framework with the unique topological architecture, by the reaction of Gd2O3, CuCl2, and HIN in the presence of HClO4, (NH4)+(HCOO)-; however, these original results not only enrich the field of pillared frameworks but also make up the blank of less-developed pillared 3d−4f framework. In addition, the coexistence of antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic correlations between gadolinium ions is also notable.
elements.clean_text: In summary, through this original study, we have successfully isolated one pillared 3d-4f framework with the unique topological architecture, by the reaction of Gd2O3, CuCl2, and HIN in the presence of HClO4, (NH4)+(HCOO)-; however, these original results not only enrich the field of pillared frameworks but also make up the blank of less-developed pillared 3d-4f framework. In addition, the coexistence of antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic correlations between gadolinium ions is also notable.

X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format, two plots, and one table. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Pillared 3d−4f Frameworks with Rare 3D Architecture Showing the Coexistence
of Ferromagnetic and Antiferromagnetic Interactions between Gadolinium Ions
